docs.snippet: THE plane was soaring 37,000 feet above America, somewhere between lunch and the movie, when Bill Cartwright of the New York Knickerbockers decided to take a stroll.   Even in the first-class cabin, a man who is 7 feet 1 inch tall will feel crampe...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE plane was soaring 37,000 feet above America, somewhere between lunch and the movie, when Bill Cartwright of the New York Knickerbockers decided to take a stroll. Even in the first-class cabin, a man who is 7 feet 1 inch tall will feel cramped, but Cartwright seemed less oversized when he bumped into the legend of Wilt Chamberlain. The collision of man with legend occurred as the Knicks flew across the country the other day. Easing his way down the aisle, the softspoken young Knick center passed the seat of Cal Ramsey, who broadcasts the Knick games on television.

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Legend of Wilt Chamberlain Flies High

docs.snippet: BILL HENDERSON, the vocalist and actor who is singing a program of Johnny Mercer songs at Michael's Pub, met the late Mr. Mercer only once.   ''Skitch Henderson introduced me to him,'' Mr. Henderson recalled the other day. ''And John Mercer said, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: BILL HENDERSON, the vocalist and actor who is singing a program of Johnny Mercer songs at Michael's Pub, met the late Mr. Mercer only once. ''Skitch Henderson introduced me to him,'' Mr. Henderson recalled the other day. ''And John Mercer said, with that magnificent Southern accent, 'Oh, you're the guy they say sounds like me - but you sound better.' '' ''I didn't think I sang like Mercer,'' Mr. Henderson continued. ''But people kept saying I sounded like him, so I felt I must be on the right track. But I was coming on the track on my own.''

headline.main: BILL HENDERSON SINGING A LA MERCER

docs.snippet: It has been 30 years since a pretty young woman from the Bronx named Roberta Peters stepped out before her first audience and was propelled into virtually instant stardom in the world of opera. The setting was the Metropolitan Opera, and her surpr...
docs.lead_paragraph: It has been 30 years since a pretty young woman from the Bronx named Roberta Peters stepped out before her first audience and was propelled into virtually instant stardom in the world of opera. The setting was the Metropolitan Opera, and her surprise debut as a lastminute stand-in for an ailing soprano in Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' created a sensation that started her on a flourishing career. Miss Peters has not missed a year at the Met since then - a longevity record for a Met soprano. ''People think I'm 105 because I've been around so long,'' she said with a laugh the other day. In fact, Miss Peters is 50 and, she says, has no thoughts of slowing down.

headline.main: ROBERTA PETERS MARKS 30 YEARS AS A SOPRANO AT MET

docs.snippet: Oscar Mayer & Company, the Middle Western meatpacking concern, has been a familiar brand in many American households. But the closely held, conservatively managed corporation, troubled recently with faltering profits, was less well regarded in the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar Mayer & Company, the Middle Western meatpacking concern, has been a familiar brand in many American households. But the closely held, conservatively managed corporation, troubled recently with faltering profits, was less well regarded in the financial community - and seemed an unlikely target for acquisition. So the announcement last weekend that Oscar Mayer was negotiating to sell out to the General Foods Corporation startled even seasoned hands in industry. Wednesday night the companies reached a formal agreement in principle to merge. However, General Foods, which rarely pursues acquisitions, has long been interested in Oscar Mayer. A couple of years ago, General Foods approached the Wisconsin company and held discussions with its management, but then backed off, according to sources close to Oscar Mayer, for two reasons.

docs.snippet: The General Foods Corporation, the nation's largest packaged foods maker, will buy Oscar Mayer & Company for about $464.6 million in cash under an agreement in principle announced by the companies yesterday.   General Foods, based in White Plains,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The General Foods Corporation, the nation's largest packaged foods maker, will buy Oscar Mayer & Company for about $464.6 million in cash under an agreement in principle announced by the companies yesterday. General Foods, based in White Plains, said last weekend it was seeking to buy Oscar Mayer, a meat procesor based in Madison, Wis., for cash and preferred stock worth about $29 for each Oscar Mayer share.

headline.main: GENERAL FOODS PLANS TO BUY OSCAR MAYER

docs.snippet: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 15.10 points yesterday as prices of former stock favorites continued to erode. It marked the eighth decline in the 10 trading sessions since President Reagan took office on January 20.   The Dow cloped at 9...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 15.10 points yesterday as prices of former stock favorites continued to erode. It marked the eighth decline in the 10 trading sessions since President Reagan took office on January 20. The Dow cloped at 932.17, which was 38 points lower than its level on the Monday before Inauguration Day, when the sell-off began with a drop of 20.31 points. In contrast to last week's performance, when steel, chemical and other basic industry issues moved ahead, only one of the Dow's 30 components showed a gain yesterday. That was Alcoa, up 1 3/8, to 62 3/4.

headline.main: Dow Falls 15.10 Points, To 932.17; Decline Eighth In 10 Sessions Under Reagan

docs.snippet: The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating for the acquisition of Oscar Mayer & Company in a stock and cash transaction valued at roughly $464.6 million.   The brief statement issued from General Foods' headquarters ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating for the acquisition of Oscar Mayer & Company in a stock and cash transaction valued at roughly $464.6 million. The brief statement issued from General Foods' headquarters in White Plains, N.Y., said that it was negotiating with Oscar Mayer to purchase the meat-processing company's outstanding stock for about $29 a share. On Friday, the value of a share of Oscar Meyer, which is based in Madison, Wis., closed up 3 3/4, to 21, on the New York Stock Exchange. There are just over 16 million shares of Oscar Mayer common stock outstanding. About 45 percent of those shares are held by the Mayer family, and much of the remainder is reportedly held by individuals and institutions close to the family.

headline.main: GENERAL FOODS NEGOTIATING A BID FOR OSCAR MAYER

docs.snippet: The philosophy that brought the Cosmos out of obscurity and made them the most glamorous team in the North American Soccer League apparently no longer prevails.   The new philosophy, advocated by everyone in the team's upper echelons, is to stop i...
docs.lead_paragraph: The philosophy that brought the Cosmos out of obscurity and made them the most glamorous team in the North American Soccer League apparently no longer prevails. The new philosophy, advocated by everyone in the team's upper echelons, is to stop importing famous players. The rationale is that the Cosmos have sufficient talent to play attractive soccer and produce their own stars. Further, the Cosmos, who brought in such world-renowned players as Pele, Franz Beckenbauer and Giorgio Chinaglia, have said that there are not enough players with worldwide appeal.

headline.main: Cosmos Shift Away From Import System

docs.snippet: --------------------------------------------------------------------  Dan Yakir, a New York freelance writer, has a special interest in films. By DAN YAKIR   ''I'm not a sex symbol,'' says Gerard Depardieu. ''I'm not even an actor, but an agitator...
docs.lead_paragraph: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dan Yakir, a New York freelance writer, has a special interest in films. By DAN YAKIR ''I'm not a sex symbol,'' says Gerard Depardieu. ''I'm not even an actor, but an agitator. I like to provoke people, even draw out their stupidity to make them aware of it. I like to be their malaise and render everything they don't want to see.'' There is irony in his words because, at the age of 32 with 39 films behind him, he not only seems to be France's most ubiquitous actor, but the one who has done most to replace the stereotype of the elegant ''French lover'' with his own working class roughness and intense physical presence. Beyond these characteristics, there is what Bertrand Blier, who directed him in ''Going Places'' and the Oscar-winning ''Get Out Your Handkerchiefs,'' terms ''a wonderful inner madness.'' In New York, the past fall and current winter have largely been Mr. Depardieu's seasons, with three of his films on display - Maurice Pialat's ''Loulou,'' Francois Truffaut's ''The Last Metro'' and Alain Resnais's ''Mon Oncle d'Amerique. ''Loulou'' and ''The Last Metro'' played at the New York Film Festival, after which ''Loulou'' enjoyed an extended commercial run that only recently ended. ''The Last Metro'' is scheduled to begin its a commercial run at Cinema II on Feb. 11. ''Mon Oncle,'' which opened in mid-December, is still playing to packed houses.

headline.main: THE ACTOR WHO CHANGED THE SCREEN'S FRENCH LOVER

docs.snippet: HARVARD ENCYCLOPEDIA OF AMERICAN ETHNIC GROUPS Stephan Thernstrom, Editor.  Ann Orlov, Managing Editor.  Oscar Handlin, Consulting Editor.  1,076 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $60.   THAT a book like this would appear was merely ...
docs.lead_paragraph: HARVARD ENCYCLOPEDIA OF AMERICAN ETHNIC GROUPS Stephan Thernstrom, Editor. Ann Orlov, Managing Editor. Oscar Handlin, Consulting Editor. 1,076 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $60. THAT a book like this would appear was merely a matter of time. The revived interest in ethnicity required a reference volume, if only to aid students struggling with term papers. But that such a work would come from Harvard, with its imprimatur in the title, might not have been predicted. After all, for most of its existence our senior university held itself aloof from ethnic America, as did most established institutions. All the more reason, therefore, to see how the Harvard Encyclopedia of American Ethnic Groups treats its subjects.

headline.main: AMERICA'S ETHNICS FROM A TO Z

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: FOREIGN POPULATION AND FOREIGN DESCENT GROUPS

byline.original: By ANDREW HACKER; Andrew Hacker teaches political science at Queens College. His most recent book is ''The New Yorkers,'' and he is currently working on a study of equality
